hints_html:
What is the augmented matrix that corresponds to this problem?

Row-reduce the augmented matrix, then consider special choices for \(\alpha\) separately.

hints_raw:
What is the augmented matrix that corresponds to this problem?
Row-reduce the augmented matrix, then consider special choices for ''&alpha;'' separately.
sols_html:
Let A be the augmented matrix, that is,

\[\begin{aligned} A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 &-1 & 1 &2 \\ -2 & 1 & \alpha &-3 \\ 1 & \alpha & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

To begin the row-reduction, we add two multiples of the first line to the second line and also subtract the first line from the third to obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 & 1 & 2 \\ -2 & 1 & \alpha &-3 \\ 1 & \alpha & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & -1 & \alpha+2 & 1 \\ 0 & \alpha+1 & -2 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 0 & \alpha+1 & -2 & -1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Then, subtract a factor of (\(\alpha\)+2) times the second row from the last row and simplify

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 0 & \alpha+1 & -2 & -1 \end{bmatrix} &\sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & (-(\alpha+2))(-(\alpha+1))-2 & -1+\alpha+1 \end{bmatrix} \\ &\sim \begin{bmatrix} 1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & \alpha(\alpha+3) & \alpha \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

We can now investigate what happens for different values of \(\alpha\). Notice that the first line doesn’t depend on \(\alpha\) and so there is nothing to conclude for the first line. For the second line, \(\alpha\) could make one of the terms vanish but there will still be a solution to that equation if this happens. Therefore, the real power of \(\alpha\) comes from the third line. We can distinguish three cases for \(\alpha\):

  • When \(\alpha\) = 0 the matrix will be \begin{bmatrix}

1 & -1 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 & -2 & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}, and there will be infinitely many solutions.

  • When \(\alpha\) = -3 the matrix will be \begin{bmatrix}

1 & -1 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & -3 \end{bmatrix}, and there will be no solution.

  • When \(\alpha\) is neither 0 nor -3, there will be a unique solution.
sols_raw:
Let ''A'' be the augmented matrix, that is,

:<math>A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 &2 \\ 
-2 & 1 & \alpha &-3 \\ 
1 & \alpha & -1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}</math>

To begin the row-reduction, we add two multiples of the first line to the second line and also subtract the first line from the third to obtain
:<math>\begin{bmatrix}
1 & -1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
-2 & 1 & \alpha &-3 \\ 
1 & \alpha & -1 & 1
\end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & -1 & \alpha+2 & 1 \\ 
0 & \alpha+1 & -2 & -1
\end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 
0 & \alpha+1 & -2 & -1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

Then, subtract a factor of ''(&alpha;+2)'' times the second row from the last row and simplify
:<math> \begin{align}
\begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 
0 & \alpha+1 & -2 & -1
\end{bmatrix} &\sim \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 
0 & 0 & (-(\alpha+2))(-(\alpha+1))-2 & -1+\alpha+1
\end{bmatrix} \\
&\sim \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -(\alpha+2) & -1 \\ 
0 & 0 & \alpha(\alpha+3) & \alpha
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align} </math>

We can now investigate what happens for different values of ''&alpha;''.  Notice that the first line doesn't depend on ''&alpha;'' and so there is nothing to conclude for the first line.  For the second line, ''&alpha;'' could make one of the terms vanish but there will still be a solution to that equation if this happens.  Therefore, the real power of ''&alpha;'' comes from the third line.  We can distinguish three cases for ''&alpha;'':
* When ''&alpha; = 0'' the matrix will be <math>\begin{bmatrix}
1 & -1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & -2 & -1 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{bmatrix}</math>, and there will be '''infinitely many solutions'''.

* When ''&alpha; = -3'' the matrix will be <math>\begin{bmatrix}
1 & -1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
0 & 1 & 1 & -1 \\ 
0 & 0 & 0 & -3
\end{bmatrix}</math>, and there will '''be no solution'''.

* When ''&alpha;'' is neither 0 nor -3, there will be a '''unique solution'''.
statement_html:
For the parameter \(\alpha\), consider the linear system:

\[\begin{aligned} x - y + z &= 2, \\ -2x + y + \alpha z &= -3, \\ x + \alpha y - z &= 1.\end{aligned}\]

Determine when the system has a unique solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions. (Don\(^{\prime}\)t determine the actual solutions!)
